conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a region where the light is not directly visible.
The size and shape of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
When the light source moves upward, it becomes more directly overhead.

premise: When the light source moves upward, it becomes more directly overhead.
conclusion: This change affects both the position and the size of the shadows.

premise: As the light source moves upward, it becomes more directly overhead.
conclusion: The shadows will shift closer to the objects casting them.

premise: As the light source moves upward, it becomes more directly overhead.
conclusion: The size of the shadows will decrease.

premise: The shadows will shift closer to the objects casting them.
conclusion: With the light source higher up, the light rays are more parallel to each other when they reach the ground, resulting in smaller shadows.
